title: 111_hr4422
content: The Act titled "Minority Entrepreneurship and Business Development Act" establishes the Minority Entrepreneurship and Business Enterprise Center Grant Program. The Director may provide grants to eligible educational institutions or organizations to establish entrepreneurship curriculum and Minority Business Enterprise Centers. Recipients must develop a curriculum including training in business management, marketing, financial management, marketing analysis, and innovation. Each eligible educational institution or organization receiving a grant must establish an entrepreneurship curriculum and a Minority Business Enterprise Center. The curriculum should include training in business management, marketing, financial management, marketing analysis, competitive analysis, and strategic planning. The Center must follow duties prescribed by the Director of the Minority Business Development Agency and cannot receive more than $1,500,000 in a fiscal year. Funds under this section cannot exceed $1,500,000 in a fiscal year or be used for purposes unrelated to developing curriculum or operating a minority business enterprise center. Grants under this Act require a 15 percent private matching grant. The Director must submit a report evaluating the success of the program each year to the Senate and House Committees on Small Business. The report should include details of entrepreneurship programs developed with grant funds. Authorization of Appropriations: $40,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2010 to 2012 to support minority business enterprise centers. Funds can only be used for this purpose. Data on participants, small businesses assisted, and economic impact must be reported. The Office of Minority Entrepreneurship and Business Development is established. The Office of Minority Entrepreneurship and Business Development is established within the Minority Business Development Agency, administered by an Associate Director for Minority Entrepreneurship and Business Development. The Associate Director is responsible for increasing counseling and training for minority start-ups and the Agency's entrepreneurial development programs, as well as increasing the proportion of the Agency's contracts to minorities. The Office of Minority Entrepreneurship and Business Development aims to increase counseling, training, and contracts to minority entrepreneurs. It also focuses on marketing resources to new and small minority-owned businesses, ensuring adequate resources for grant programs, and reporting directly to the Director. Authorization of appropriations includes $7,000,000 for fiscal year 2010 and 2011. The Office of Minority Entrepreneurship and Business Development aims to increase support for minority entrepreneurs with $7,000,000 authorized for fiscal year 2011 and 2012. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the terms "Agency" and "Director" refer to the Minority Small Business Development Agency and its Director. The term "eligible association or organization" includes minority business associations exempt from taxation under the Internal Revenue Code. The term "eligible educational institution" refers to a public or private higher education institution, including historically Black colleges, Hispanic-serving institutions, Asian-serving institutions, and Native Hawaiian-serving institutions, that has been in existence for at least 5 years before receiving a grant under section 2. The term "historically Black college" refers to a part B institution as defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965. The term "Hispanic-serving institution" is defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965. The term "institution of higher education" is defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965. The term "small business concern" is defined in the Small Business Act. The term "tribal college" has the same meaning as "tribally controlled college or university". The term "tribally controlled college or university" is defined under the Tribally Controlled Community College Assistance Act of 1978.
